awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Characterizing Active Learning Environments in Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will improve tools to distinguish between active learning environments and is significant to both physics specifically and STEM education generally. Evidence that active learning is superior to purely passive lecturing is decisive, so STEM education research must now build a better vocabulary for comparing active environments. This work will study several "flagship" curricula in university physics, describing those classrooms using a common observation framework and social network analysis to examine student collaboration. The project will compare classroom features and student networks between these high-impact examples, and will also promote tools for faculty to gather similar information about their own classrooms.

The goals of this project are: to characterize the social network development within several research-validated active learning curricula; to use the Classroom Observation Protocol for Undergraduate STEM (COPUS) to begin to build a standardized vocabulary to compare these environments; and to begin to link specific features of learning environments with the characteristics of student social networks that develop over the semester. Student networks will form the focal measure of the work because of the prominence of student-student interactions in virtually all active learning curricula. Data on this classroom aspect currently lag far behind the detail available for individual-cognitive measures such as conceptual gains. This project will address that deficiency while simultaneously documenting the classroom features that support or constrain these collaborative networks. Data collected will include network surveys and detailed classroom observations from six research-validated curricula. Analyses will include comparison and time evolution of degree distributions, network structure and centralization, and linear modeling combining network metrics with profiles identified from COPUS analysis.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this IUSE project was to begin developing a better vocabulary to compare active learning environments in physics to each other. This work will enable researchers to move beyond the "lecture vs. active learning" dichotomies that have dominated research in university science education. It will also help instructors in planning for active and engaging classrooms. During this project, the research team visited well-regarded implementation sites for six prominent active learning curricula in physics. We collected classroom observations and data on student interaction networks at each site.

Early- and late-semester student interaction networks were compared by size and structural characteristics. We found that all the pedagogy types showed an increase in network connectivity over the semester, but significant changes in the amount of network structure were only observed in a few curricula. Classroom observations were analyzed with latent profile analysis, a technique for categorizing multidimensional observations into sub-groups. We found that observation codes grouped into two- or five-profile solutions. Roughly, the two-profile solution distinguishes "lecture-like" from "activity-like" environments. The five-category solution has finer distinctions that show promise for characterizing curriculum types.

As a preliminary study and "proof of concept," this project produced promising results. The next steps to expand this work are:

1. To collect data at more sites to see if the initial network and observation profile results recur at different sites for a particular curriculum
2. To collect data on student outcomes to analyze in conjunction with the classroom observation and network profiles

Additionally, the data collection and analysis methods used in this project are not unique to physics, and could be extended to other science and mathematics classrooms.

The longer-term goals of the project are to advance comparison of active learning classrooms beyond a simple "lecture vs. active learning" dichotomy, in keeping with current recommendations in STEM education research. Developing a vocabulary and visualization tools for these differences will help instructors to choose active learning techniques and curricula that fit their local contexts and teaching style.
